message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The history and physical examination suggest a tear of the anterior cruciate ligament (ACL). The ACL originates from the posteromedial aspect of the lateral femoral condyle.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The anterior translation with the anterior drawer test suggests injury to the anterior cruciate ligament (ACL). The ACL originates from the posteromedial aspect of the lateral femoral condyle, so the correct answer is (C). The other structures are not related to the ACL.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The findings indicate injury to the anterior cruciate ligament (ACL), which originates from the posteromedial aspect of the lateral femoral condyle. A significant anterior translation during Lachman test also supports this diagnosis. Options A and B refer to the origin of the lateral and medial collateral ligaments, respectively, which are not likely to be injured in this scenario. Option D refers to the insertion of the patellar tendon.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The suprapatellar effusion, limited flexion, and anterior translation during the exam indicate an ACL injury. ACL originates on the posteromedial aspect of the lateral femoral condyle. Option (A) refers to the lateral collateral ligament, (B) refers to the medial collateral ligament, and (D) refers to the patellar tendon.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest a possible ACL tear, which arises from the posteromedial aspect of the lateral femoral condyle. The anterior translation observed during the Lachman test suggests an ACL tear, and the other options do not involve the ACL.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a history of twisting his knee, has a diffuse pain, and has a notable suprapatellar effusion. The anterior translation test showed 1.5 cm of translation on the affected knee and 0.5 cm on the contralateral knee. The injured structure is likely the anterior cruciate ligament (ACL), which originates on the posteromedial aspect of the lateral femoral condyle.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The history and exam findings suggest an anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) injury. The ACL originates from the posteromedial aspect of the lateral femoral condyle.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with symptoms and signs of ACL injury. The ACL originates from the posteromedial aspect of the lateral femoral condyle (option C). The other options are incorrect as they refer to other structures in the knee.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of the injury and the findings on exam suggest a tear of the anterior cruciate ligament (ACL). The ACL originates from the posteromedial aspect of the lateral femoral condyle. Options A and B are incorrect as they refer to the origin of the lateral collateral ligament and medial collateral ligament, respectively. Option D refers to the insertion of the patellar tendon.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient experiences instability and has a positive anterior drawer test, indicating a possible torn anterior cruciate ligament. The ACL originates from the posteromedial aspect of the lateral femoral condyle.
